revised_title: Modeling Cretaceous Climate: The Role of Geography and Carbon Dioxide
tldr: This study uses a general circulation model to assess the role of continental geography and increased levels of carbon dioxide in explaining the warmth of the Cretaceous period. The model suggests that geography has a negligible role, and higher atmospheric carbon dioxide levels (4 times present) resulted in a 5.5°C globally averaged surface temperature increase, which could explain the warmth of the Cretaceous era.
